description.p: The tattooed elf stands victorious over the body of a newly slain frost giant, his axes dripping with blood and the runes marking his body glowing after having deflected the giant’s brutal assault. He raises his axes and shouts a victorious cry. The low crash of thunder can be heard in the distance. The gods are pleased.

The red-haired genasi hammers away at a beautifully crafted sword. The snow flurries around him as he thrusts the sword into his forge. He takes it out to examine the carved rune, glowing with blue light. It hums with anticipation.

The young human pants as he reaches the top of the lone mountain. He looks around, the cursed wood stretching as far as the eye could see. He breathes the cold, brisk morning air and sits down to watch the sun rise. Here he would sit until the secrets of the universe revealed themselves. And he would not leave until he knew why they had wronged him.

Warrior, soldier, pirate, or hermit, a true Viking is defined by their knowledge of the runes that embody all aspects of the universe. Vikings are skilled fighters who weave aspects of the runes into their martial prowess to gain an advantage in battle.

Runes embody all aspects of the universe. Vikings study these runes and their aspects to gain an edge in battle. A Viking can utter runes in the midst of combat to harness elements through Isaz and Kenaz, or imbue her weapon with power through Berkanan. They can also be used outside of battle. A trained Viking can harness sustenance from runes and never go hungry or thirsty so long as he remembers Fehu or Laguz.

Vikings hail from cold, frigid climates. Their homelands are generally sprawling plains and forests, littered with ancient mountain ranges. Their people farm and trade, but they themselves train for and go on seafaring expeditions, usually in order to raid coastal villages and towns for goods. A viking’s goal is to die in battle in order to join their gods. They generally believe in some form of final battle that they will all take part in.

However, the way a viking chooses to go about that is different from individual to individual. Perhaps they choose to wait it out and hone their skills until the time is right, or they choose a life of adventure, knowing full well that something out there will be the end of them. The way they live is up to them and them alone. But the way of their death, they believe, is in the hands of Fate, and that is where it will stay.

An important aspect of creating a Viking is to determine their combat expertise. Do you want to create a frontline berserker that can soak up hits from enemies and protects allies via a shield? Or do you want to play a versatile, druidic warrior that uses runes to regularly enhance their combat ability as well as everyday life?

How did your viking come to learn the runes? Was it through months and years of study? Or was it a revelation from your gods, found in the aftermath of a bloody battle, or perhaps on a lone mountaintop after days of contemplation?

Most importantly, however, is how you choose to harness these newfound runes. Do you paint and scar your body with the runes as a reminder of your accomplishment? Do you etch them on your blades and hammers to show proudly? Or perhaps you stick to uttering them, and instead spend your time unlocking more of the universe’s secrets. After all, there are always more to be found.

You can build a Viking quickly after following these suggestions. First, strength should be your highest score, followed by constitution, or wisdom if you plan to choose the Font of the Noose. Second, choose the soldier background. Third, pick the Isaz, Kenaz, and Berkanan runes.
As an viking, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per viking level after 1st
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, chain mail, shields
Skills: Choose two from Athletics, Intimidation, Survival, Religion, Perception

description.p: At 1st level, you begin to learn the full power of the 24 Futhark Runes, all of which are detailed after the class description. Using a bonus action to utter a Rune allows you to use it's effect in battle as well as outside of it. At 1st level you memorize three Runes. Every time you take a short or long rest, you can choose to replace a Rune you have memorized with a new Rune. You can utter a number of Runes equal to half your Viking level, rounded up, up to a maximum of 10 per short or long rest. Your Save DC for Runes is equal to 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Wisdom modifier.

sheet.description: You utter a Rune to use it's effect in battle as well as outside of it. The Save DC for your Runes is {{runes:dc}}.

description.p: At 2nd level, you adopt a style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2. The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.
When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.
When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

When you reach 3rd level, you dedicate yourself to one of the three ancient Runic Fonts. The Font of Paints, the Font of the Forge, and the Font of the Noose, each of which is detailed at the end of the class description.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 7th, 11th, 15th, and 20th level.

Also at 3rd level, you learn to travel better in snowstorms and blizzards. You gain advantage on Constitution saves to resist extreme cold. You also gain advantage on Survival checks while in snow and blizzards.

sheet.description: You have advantage on Constitution saves to resist extreme cold. You also have advantage on Survival checks while in snow and blizzards.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th. and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

At 5th level, you become proficient in fighting others in close quarters. At 5th level, then again at 10th, 14th, and 18th level, you choose one of the following features to add to your combat arsenal. Your save DC for these features is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier:

Parry: If an attack made by a creature you can see within melee range would hit you, you can use your reaction to add +3 to your AC against that attack. You must be wielding a shield or melee weapon to use this benefit.

Shield Bash: If an attack made by a creature you can see within melee range fails to hit you, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack againt it using your shield. On a successful attack, it deals 2d4 bludgeoning damage. You must be using a shield to gain this benefit.

Bull Rush: If you move at least 15 feet in a straight line and make a successful attack against a creature that is the same size as you or smaller, you can choose to use a bonus action to Bull Rush it. The target must make a Strength save. On a failed save, you can carry it up to your remaining movement and throw it to the ground, knocking it prone.
Stalwart: As long as there are two or more creatures hostile to you within 5 feet of you, you gain an additional +1 to AC for each enemy beyond the second.

Sweep: After making a successful attack against a creature that is up to one size larger than you, you can use a bonus action to sweep that enemy off it’s feet. The target must make a Strength save. On a failed save it is knocked prone.

Headbutt: On your turn you can use your attack action to headbutt an enemy you can see within 5 feet of you. The target must make a Constitution save. On a failed save, the target is stunned until the end of it’s next turn.
Drag: You can move a grappled creature up to your max movement speed as long as the grappled creature is the same size as you or smaller.
Headlock: As long as you are grappling a creature, you can use a bonus action to deal 1d4 bludgeoning damage to it.

sheet.description: Your Close Combat save DC is {{close-combat:dc}}.

description.p: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn

description.p: At 6th level, you have learned to use adrenaline on the battlefield to drive and motivate your allies.

As a bonus action, you can shout a battlecry, causing any allies that can hear you to gain advantage on their next attack roll. Additionally, those creatures each gain a d6 Inspiration die for 1 minute. This feature cannot be used again until you complete a long rest.

sheet.description: You can shout a battlecry, causing any allies that can hear you to gain advantage on their next attack roll. Additionally, those creatures each gain a d6 Inspiration die for 1 minute.

description.p: At 6th level, you have been trained to excel at grappling foes. You have advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks for grappling a target that is the same size as you or smaller. Once grappled, that creature has disadvantage on escaping the grapple.

At 11th level, you have trained yourself to be able to grapple foes up to two sizes larger than you, however you have disadvantage on Strength (Athletics) checks for grappling a creature that is two sizes larger than you. That creature has advantage on escaping the grapple.

description.p: Beginning at 9th level, your knowledge of Runes has vastly improved. You are now able to memorize, forge, and tattoo more potent and powerful Runes.
Beginning at 14th level, it becomes more difficult for your foes to take you down.
As long as you are under half your maximum Hit Points, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons.

sheet.description: As long as you are under half your maximum Hit Points, you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons.

description.p: At 18th level, you have learned to optimize fighting with your allies as a group.
As long as you are within 30 feet of allies that you can see and/or hear, you and those allies can choose to reroll a single damage die each turn and choose which to keep.

sheet.description: As long as you are within 30 feet of allies that you can see and/or hear, you and those allies can choose to reroll a single damage die each turn and choose which to keep.

description.p: At 20th level, you have become a champion of your gods. Cold no longer affects you, in fact the very essence of winter and sea follow you wherever you go.
You gain immunity to cold damage, and resistance to fire damage. Additionally, melee attack rolls that you make are imbued with cold, dealing an additional 1d10 cold damage on every successful hit.

sheet.description: Cold no longer affects you, in fact the very essence of winter and sea follow you wherever you go. You gain immunity to cold damage, and resistance to fire damage. Additionally, melee attack rolls that you make are imbued with cold, dealing an additional 1d10 cold damage on every successful hit.

description.p: The Font of Paints allows a Viking to mark Runes upon their body, and temporarily upon the bodies of their allies to provide protection and augmentation.

At 3rd level, you learn to tattoo yourself with certain runes. Tattooing Runes takes an hour per Rune and 5sp in inks, or you can take an additional hour to scavenge pigments from the surrounding land beforehand. You can not have more than one of the same Rune tattooed at any given time. You can tattoo yourself with a number of tattoos equal to half your Viking level, rounded up. The Runes you tattoo can be different from those you have memorized. You then gain 1d6 temporary hit points for each Rune on your body.
Upon reaching 0 temporary hit points, you may use your reaction to expend a hit die and reroll the temporary hit points for each tattoo. The tattoos fade when you are unable to regenerate them.
Replacing an existing Rune on yourself takes 2 hours. Refer to the table at the end of the class description to discern which Runes can be tattooed as well as their effects.

sheet.description: You can tattoo yourself with a number of tattoos equal to half your Viking level, rounded up. The Runes you tattoo can be different from those you have memorized. You then gain 1d{{runic-tattoos:dice}} temporary hit points for each Rune on your body. Upon reaching 0 temporary hit points, you may use your reaction to expend a hit die and reroll the temporary hit points for each tattoo. The tattoos fade when you are unable to regenerate them.

description.p: Beginning at 7th level, you are able to temporarily mark your allies with Runes. An ally may only be marked with one Rune at a time, and requires the same amount of materials. Marks on allies last for one day and cannot be regenerated. They are also removed when submerged in running water.
Additionally, tattooing yourself or allies can now be done during a short rest.

sheet.description: You are able to temporarily mark your allies with Runes. An ally may only be marked with one Rune at a time, and requires the same amount of materials. Marks on allies last for one day and cannot be regenerated. They are also removed when submerged in running water.

description.p: Beginning at 11th level, you gain +1 to AC for every three runes marked upon your body.

sheet.description: You gain +1 to AC for every three runes marked upon your body.

description.p: Starting at 15th level, any Runes you tattoo yourself with give you 1d8 temporary hit points per Rune instead of 1d6.
At 20th level, you gain the ability to strengthen the bodies of your marked allies as well as yourself using your voice.

You can use an action to shout a warcry, causing the runes on your body as well as any runes on your allies to ignite, shedding dim light in a 20 foot radius. Additionally, you and those allies gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons and can reroll temporary hit points for each Rune on your bodies - you may choose to use this new total or keep your original total. These effects, save for the temporary hit points, last 1 minute. This feature cannot be used again until you complete a long rest.

description.p: The Font of the Forge teaches a Viking the essentials of smithing weapons and armor as well as the ability to forge runes into weapons, infusing the essence of the rune with the item it is forged into.
At 3rd level, you begin to learn how to forge weapons and armor. You gain proficiency in Smith’s tools.
Additionally, you are able to etch Runes into weapons, altering their essence to serve the blade. Etching a weapon takes a day, as well as 100gp worth of materials, which the process consumes.

A weapon can have only one Rune etched on it, the Rune must be one you have memorized while you etch it. Once etched, the Rune cannot be removed or replaced. Additionally, an etched weapon counts as a magical weapon for the purposes of overcoming resistances.
Refer to the table at the end of the class description to discern which Runes can be etched on weapons as well as their effects.

Starting at 7th level, etching a Rune onto a weapon now also grants it the +1 property. Weapons with previously etched Runes can be reworked over the course of a day, using up 5gp worth of materials, which the process consumes, to grant them this property.

sheet.description: Etching a Rune onto a weapon now also grants it the +1 property.

description.p: Starting at 11th level, you become a master of martial weaponry. You are able to choose a second option from the Fighting Style feature. Additionally, you are able to score a critical hit with a melee weapon on a roll of 19 or 20.

sheet.description: You score a critical hit with a melee weapon on a roll of 19 or 20.

description.p: Starting at 15th level, you are able to etch up to two Runes on any weapon. Etching an additional Rune requires an additional day as well as 100gp worth of materials, which the process consumes.
You can instead also choose to replace a Rune that has been etched on a weapon. This feature can only be used once per weapon.

sheet.description: You are able to etch up to two Runes on any weapon. Etching an additional Rune requires an additional day as well as 100gp worth of materials, which the process consumes. description.p: At 20th level, you are able to overload any weapon etched with a Rune of your choice. When you utter a Rune, you can choose to activate every instance of the same Rune that has been etched on a weapon within 50 feet of you instead of the Rune’s usual effect.

Doing so causes each weapon etched with the uttered Rune to glow with bright light in a 10 foot radius. Additionally, on a successful attack with each of those weapons, that weapon deals an additional damage die of that weapons type for each Rune etched on it.
This feature lasts 1 minute and cannot be used again until after a long rest.

description.p: The Font of the Noose requires a Viking to dedicate themselves to knowledge of the forces of nature and the earth that surrounds them, giving them access to druidic magic, as well as the ability to create their own runes if they wish to truly dedicate themselves.
At 3rd level, you begin to understand the very workings of the earth you walk on. You gain access to a limited amount of druid spells to use.
You learn two cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list. You learn an additional druid cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

The Font of the Noose Spellcasting table shows you how many spell slots you have to cast your druid spells of 1st level or higher. To cast one of these spells you must expend a spell slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
You know three 1st-level druid spells of your choice.

The Spells Known column of the Font of the Noose Spellcasting table shows when you learn more druid spells of 1st-level or higher. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the druid spells you know with another spell of your choice from the druid spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells. You use your Wisdom modifier whenever a spell refers to your spellcastng ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Starting at 7th level, you learn to focus your knowledge to create Runes by studying the Well of Urd. These Runes are weaker than the existing Runes but can be bent to serve a more specific purpose.

Working with your DM, you are able to create your own Runes and decide their effects over the course of several days. Your DM decides whether or not creating the Rune has any additional costs and exactly how much time you need to dedicate to creating it.
Once created, any Runes you have created act as though they are part of the initial list of 24 Runes.
